author: Paul Gilder
title: ASX 200 leads way in $37 billion bounceback
text:
AUSTRALIA’S share market has outshone its major Asian counterparts, staging a dramatic rebound as investors shrugged off fears of a Chinese slowdown and another steep decline on global indices.
Just a day after its biggest rout since the global financial crisis, the nation’s benchmark share index chalked up its biggest rally in almost four years.
Investors took a chance to snap up banking and healthcare stocks after Monday’s mayhem stirred bargain hunters.
In a volatile trading session, the ASX 200 plunged 1.5 per cent on the opening bell on Tuesday only to claw its way back to positive territory late in the morning.
It then surged ahead, closing up 2.7 per cent to deliver a $37.3 billion turnaround from a day earlier, when the bourse haemorrhaged nearly $60 billion in value.
The rally — the best since October 2011 — came despite another plunge in China’s benchmark share index.
After plummeting 8.5 per cent on Monday as market regulators refrained from intervening, the Shanghai Composite had another day to forget, tumbling 7.6 per cent.
In Australia, the financial sector led all comers, closing 3.9 per cent higher, while healthcare stocks rose 2.1 per cent.
Beaten down a day earlier, Westpac was the best performer among the big four banks, rising 4.9 per cent to $30.90 with its major peers also up brightly.
Dollars and Sense. Picture: Macca
The local market had been shaping up for another horror show after America’s benchmark Dow Jones Industrial Average retreated 3.6 per cent overnight on Monday and European bourses suffered average falls of about 4.7 per cent.
Instead, Australia proved the glittering jewel of the Asia Pacific, leaving in its wake Japan’s Nikkei, down 4 per cent, and Hong Kong’s Hang Seng, up just 0.7 per cent.
Analysts said China’s government appeared to have bitten the bullet on attempting to prop up shares, conceding the move was proving too costly.
CMC Markets chief strategist Michael McCarthy said the swift recovery on the ASX 200 indicated investors had their eyes on America’s stuttering bull market rather than China’s economic slowdown.
“It is not weakness in China that is driving the global sell-off. It is the fact that the US share market has run without a correction since the first quarter of 2012 ... that’s a very long period without a breather,” Mr McCarthy said.
Montgomery Fund chief investment officer Roger Montgomery said the volatility meant the US Federal Reserve would be unlikely to lift interest rates next month and risk derailing its economic revival.
At home, the Reserve Bank also appears locked into record-low rates, albeit with a small chance of a further cut before January. “As disappointing as it sounds, central banks are listening to the markets,” Mr Montgomery said.
“There is a concern that if share markets fall, consumers are less inclined to borrow and spend money.”
China’s growing pains have dominated headlines but ANZ chief executive Mike Smith, who has spearheaded the lender’s push into Asia, said he wasn’t concerned.
“Fundamentally, looking at the medium and long term, China has still got huge potential ... should we be worried about it? I don’t think so,” he told a conference on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, China’s central bank said it injected 150 billion yuan ($32.1 billion) into money markets, giving banks more freedom to lend cash in hope of stimulating investment.
